description: Explore robot kinematics, control systems, sensors, and autonomous systems

slides.title: Welcome to Robotics
slides.content:
# Introduction to Robotics

Welcome to **Robotics** - machines that move and think!

## What You Will Learn:
- **Robot Kinematics** - Motion and geometry
- **Control Systems** - Making robots move
- **Sensors** - Robot perception
- **Actuators** - Creating motion
- **Autonomous Systems** - Self-driving robots

> **Fun Fact:** The word 'robot' comes from the Czech word 'robota' meaning forced labor!

slides.title: Types of Robots
slides.content:
# Types of Robots

## By Application:

| Type | Application |
|------|-------------|
| Industrial | Manufacturing, assembly |
| Service | Healthcare, hospitality |
| Mobile | Exploration, delivery |
| Humanoid | Research, entertainment |
| Medical | Surgery, rehabilitation |

## By Configuration:
- Articulated (arm-like)
- Cartesian (XYZ axes)
- SCARA (horizontal plane)
- Delta (parallel linkages)
- Mobile (wheels, legs)

## Degrees of Freedom (DOF):
- Number of independent motions
- Typical arm: 6 DOF

slides.title: Robot Kinematics
slides.content:
# Robot Kinematics

## Definition:
Study of motion without considering forces.

## Forward Kinematics:
- Given: Joint angles
- Find: End effector position

## Inverse Kinematics:
- Given: Desired position
- Find: Required joint angles
- Often multiple solutions

## Coordinate Frames:
- Base frame (fixed)
- End effector frame
- Transformation matrices

## Denavit-Hartenberg:
- Standard notation for robot links
- 4 parameters per joint
- Chain transformations

slides.title: Control Systems Basics
slides.content:
# Control Systems

## Open Loop:
- No feedback
- Command sent, hope for best

## Closed Loop:
- Feedback from sensors
- Compare to desired state
- Adjust accordingly

## PID Control:
```
u(t) = Kp*e + Ki*integral(e) + Kd*de/dt
```
- P: Proportional to error
- I: Integral of past errors
- D: Rate of change of error

## Tuning:
- Adjust Kp, Ki, Kd
- Trade-offs: Speed vs stability
- Ziegler-Nichols method

slides.title: Sensors
slides.content:
# Robot Sensors

## Proprioceptive (Internal):

| Sensor | Measures |
|--------|----------|
| Encoder | Joint position |
| Potentiometer | Angular position |
| IMU | Orientation, acceleration |
| Force/Torque | Interaction forces |

## Exteroceptive (External):

| Sensor | Measures |
|--------|----------|
| Camera | Vision |
| Lidar | Distance (laser) |
| Ultrasonic | Distance (sound) |
| Infrared | Proximity |
| Touch | Contact |

## Sensor Fusion:
- Combine multiple sensors
- Improve accuracy
- Kalman filter

slides.title: Actuators
slides.content:
# Actuators

## Electric Motors:

| Type | Properties |
|------|------------|
| DC | Simple, variable speed |
| Stepper | Precise positioning |
| Servo | Feedback controlled |
| Brushless DC | High efficiency |

## Hydraulic:
- High force output
- Heavy machinery
- Requires fluid system

## Pneumatic:
- Compressed air
- Fast, simple
- Lower precision

## Other:
- Piezoelectric
- Shape memory alloy
- Artificial muscles

slides.title: Computer Vision
slides.content:
# Computer Vision

## Tasks:
- Object detection
- Object recognition
- Tracking
- Pose estimation

## Techniques:

| Technique | Use |
|-----------|-----|
| Edge detection | Find boundaries |
| Feature matching | Identify objects |
| Stereo vision | 3D depth |
| Deep learning | Complex recognition |

## Cameras:
- RGB cameras
- Depth cameras (ToF, structured light)
- Stereo pairs

## Applications:
- Pick and place
- Navigation
- Quality inspection

slides.title: Path Planning
slides.content:
# Path Planning

## Goal:
Find path from start to goal avoiding obstacles.

## Configuration Space:
- All possible robot configurations
- Obstacles mapped to C-space

## Algorithms:

| Algorithm | Type |
|-----------|------|
| A* | Graph search |
| Dijkstra | Shortest path |
| RRT | Random sampling |
| PRM | Probabilistic roadmap |
| Potential fields | Gradient following |

## Motion Planning:
- Path + timing
- Velocity profiles
- Trajectory optimization

slides.title: SLAM
slides.content:
# SLAM

**Simultaneous Localization and Mapping**

## Challenge:
- Where am I?
- What does environment look like?
- Chicken and egg problem

## Approaches:
- Extended Kalman Filter (EKF)
- Particle filter
- Graph-based SLAM

## Sensors Used:
- Lidar (common)
- Camera (visual SLAM)
- IMU (assist)

## Applications:
- Autonomous vehicles
- Vacuum robots
- Drones
- AR/VR

slides.title: Autonomous Systems
slides.content:
# Autonomous Systems

## Levels of Autonomy:

| Level | Description |
|-------|-------------|
| 0 | Manual control |
| 1 | Assisted |
| 2 | Partial automation |
| 3 | Conditional automation |
| 4 | High automation |
| 5 | Full automation |

## Components:
- Perception
- Localization
- Planning
- Control
- Decision making

## Examples:
- Self-driving cars
- Delivery drones
- Warehouse robots
- Mars rovers

slides.title: Industrial Robotics
slides.content:
# Industrial Robotics

## Applications:
- Welding
- Painting
- Assembly
- Pick and place
- Material handling

## Key Specs:
- Payload capacity
- Reach
- Repeatability
- Speed

## Safety:
- Fenced cells
- Light curtains
- Collaborative robots (cobots)
- Force limiting

## Programming:
- Teach pendant
- Offline programming
- Lead-through teaching

slides.title: Summary
slides.content:
# Robotics Summary

## Kinematics:
- Forward: Angles -> Position
- Inverse: Position -> Angles

## Control:
- PID: Proportional, Integral, Derivative
- Feedback loops

## Sensors and Actuators:
| Sensors | Actuators |
|---------|----------|
| Encoders, cameras | DC motors |
| Lidar, IMU | Servos, steppers |

## Autonomous:
- SLAM for mapping
- Path planning
- Computer vision

## Applications:
- Industrial, service, mobile

> **Congratulations!** You've completed Robotics!
